content.title: Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA/EVLT)
content.definition: Minimally invasive thermal ablation technique using laser energy to cause thermal damage to the vein wall, resulting in fibrosis and occlusion of incompetent saphenous veins. Common wavelengths include 810nm, 940nm, 980nm, 1320nm, and 1470nm.

key_concepts.description: Laser energy absorbed by hemoglobin and water causes heating of blood and vein wall → endothelial destruction → fibrosis → vein occlusion. Continuous energy delivery along vein length
Earlier wavelengths (810-980nm) target hemoglobin - more pain, bruising. Newer wavelengths (1320-1470nm) target water - more direct wall heating, less pain, less bruising
Energy delivered per centimeter of vein (J/cm); target typically 60-80 J/cm; higher for larger veins; determines efficacy and safety
Symptomatic GSV or SSV reflux; CEAP C2-C6; similar to RFA; may be better for larger diameter veins (>12mm)
Ultrasound-guided access; laser fiber advanced to SFJ (positioned 2cm from junction); tumescent anesthesia; continuous or pulsed laser activation with slow pullback (1-2 mm/second)
Essential for all thermal ablation; provides anesthesia, compresses vein for fiber-wall contact, creates thermal buffer protecting perivenous tissue
Bare tip: forward-firing, higher focal temperatures, more perforation risk. Radial tip: 360° emission, more uniform heating, less perforation, less pain
Occlusion rates >93% at 5 years; equivalent to stripping and RFA; faster recovery than surgery; office-based outpatient procedure
Bruising (more than RFA); pain (more than RFA); paresthesia (saphenous nerve); DVT/EHIT (<1%); skin burns; vein perforation (bare tip)
Endovenous heat-induced thrombosis: Class 1 = thrombus at SFJ but not extending into femoral vein; Class 2 = extends <50% into femoral; Class 3 = >50%; Class 4 = complete DVT. Guides anticoagulation.

content.statement: Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA/EVLT) is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Procedures Laser-Ablation that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA/EVLT) helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA/EVLT) include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA/EVLT).

learning_objectives: Understand the mechanism of laser thermal ablation
Know the significance of wavelength selection
clinical_pearls: 1470nm wavelength = less pain and bruising than older wavelengths
LEED 60-80 J/cm is typical target dose
More bruising/pain than RFA but similar efficacy
Radial fiber = safer, more uniform heating than bare tip
EHIT Class 1-2 = aspirin + surveillance; Class 3-4 = anticoagulation
Position fiber 2cm from SFJ like RFA
common_mistakes: Using excessive energy (LEED >100 J/cm) - more complications
Using bare tip fiber near SFJ (perforation risk)
Not checking for EHIT on follow-up ultrasound
